controls.title: RHEL 9 user account passwords for new users or password changes must have a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction in /etc/login.defs.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: For password-based authentication, enforce organization-defined composition and complexity rules.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system enforces maximum password lifetime restrictions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 user account passwords for new users or password changes must have a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction in /etc/login.defs.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to enforce a 60-day maximum password lifetime.

Add or modify the following line in the "/etc/login.defs" file:

PASS_MAX_DAYS 60

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked; therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If the operating system does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that the operating system passwords could be compromised.

Setting the password maximum age ensures users are required to periodically change their passwords. Requiring shorter password lifetimes increases the risk of users writing down the password in a convenient location subject to physical compromise.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 user account passwords must have a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: For password-based authentication, enforce organization-defined composition and complexity rules.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system enforces maximum password lifetime restrictions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 user account passwords must have a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure noncompliant accounts to enforce a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction.

passwd -x 60 [user]

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked; therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If RHEL 9 does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that RHEL 9 passwords could be compromised.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: All RHEL 9 local interactive user accounts must be assigned a home directory upon creation.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All RHEL 9 local interactive user accounts must be assigned a home directory upon creation.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to assign home directories to all new local interactive users by setting the "CREATE_HOME" parameter in "/etc/login.defs" to "yes" as follows.

CREATE_HOME yes

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: If local interactive users are not assigned a valid home directory, there is no place for the storage and control of files they should own.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must set the umask value to 077 for all local interactive user accounts.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must set the umask value to 077 for all local interactive user accounts.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Remove the umask statement from all local interactive user's initialization files. 

If the account is for an application, the requirement for a umask less restrictive than "077" can be documented with the information system security officer, but the user agreement for access to the account must specify that the local interactive user must log on to their account first and then switch the user to the application account with the correct option to gain the account's environment variables.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files. A umask of 077 limits new files to mode 600 or less permissive. Although umask can be represented as a four-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be "0". This requirement applies to the globally configured system defaults and the local interactive user defaults for each account on the system.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 duplicate User IDs (UIDs) must not exist for interactive users.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Generate audit records containing the organization-defined additional information that is to be included in the audit records.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Uniquely identify and authenticate organizational users and associate that unique identification with processes acting on behalf of those users.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Uniquely identify and authenticate non-organizational users or processes acting on behalf of non-organizational users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 duplicate User IDs (UIDs) must not exist for interactive users.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Edit the file "/etc/passwd" and provide each interactive user account that has a duplicate UID with a unique UID.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
To ensure accountability and prevent unauthenticated access, interactive users must be identified and authenticated to prevent potential misuse and compromise of the system.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000104-GPOS-00051, SRG-OS-000121-GPOS-00062, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 system accounts must not have an interactive login shell.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 system accounts must not have an interactive login shell.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 so that all noninteractive accounts on the system do not have an interactive shell assigned to them.

If the system account needs a shell assigned for mission operations, document the need with the information system security officer (ISSO).

Run the following command to disable the interactive shell for a specific noninteractive user account:

Replace <user> with the user that has a login shell.

$ sudo usermod --shell /sbin/nologin <user>

Do not perform the steps in this section on the root account. Doing so will cause the system to become inaccessible.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: Ensuring shells are not given to system accounts upon login makes it more difficult for attackers to make use of system accounts.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must automatically expire temporary accounts within 72 hours.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Automatically remove or disable temporary and emergency accounts after an organization-defined time-period for each type of account.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Automatically remove or disable emergency accounts after an organization-defined time period for each type of account.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must automatically expire temporary accounts within 72 hours.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure the operating system to expire temporary accounts after 72 hours with the following command:

$ sudo chage -E $(date -d +3days +%Y-%m-%d) <temporary_account_name>

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Temporary accounts are privileged or nonprivileged accounts that are established during pressing circumstances, such as new software or hardware configuration or an incident response, where the need for prompt account activation requires bypassing normal account authorization procedures. If any inactive temporary accounts are left enabled on the system and are not either manually removed or automatically expired within 72 hours, the security posture of the system will be degraded and exposed to exploitation by unauthorized users or insider threat actors.

Temporary accounts are different from emergency accounts. Emergency accounts, also known as "last resort" or "break glass" accounts, are local logon accounts enabled on the system for emergency use by authorized system administrators to manage a system when standard logon methods are failing or not available. Emergency accounts are not subject to manual removal or scheduled expiration requirements.

The automatic expiration of temporary accounts may be extended as needed by the circumstances but it must not be extended indefinitely. A documented permanent account should be established for privileged users who need long-term maintenance accounts.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000123-GPOS-00064, SRG-OS-000002-GPOS-00002

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: All RHEL 9 interactive users must have a primary group that exists.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Uniquely identify and authenticate organizational users and associate that unique identification with processes acting on behalf of those users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All RHEL 9 interactive users must have a primary group that exists.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure the system so that all GIDs are referenced in "/etc/passwd" are defined in "/etc/group".

Edit the file "/etc/passwd" and ensure that every user's GID is a valid GID.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: If a user is assigned the Group Identifier (GID) of a group that does not exist on the system, and a group with the GID is subsequently created, the user may have unintended rights to any files associated with the group.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must disable account identifiers (individuals, groups, roles, and devices) after 35 days of inactivity.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Disable accounts when the accounts have expired.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Disable accounts when the accounts are no longer associated to a user.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The organization manages information system identifiers by disabling the identifier after an organization-defined time period of inactivity.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must disable account identifiers (individuals, groups, roles, and devices) after 35 days of inactivity.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to disable account identifiers after 35 days of inactivity after the password expiration. 

Run the following command to change the configuration for useradd:

$ sudo useradd -D -f 35

The recommendation is 35 days, but a lower value is acceptable.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Inactive identifiers pose a risk to systems and applications because attackers may exploit an inactive identifier and potentially obtain undetected access to the system.

Disabling inactive accounts ensures that accounts which may not have been responsibly removed are not available to attackers who may have compromised their credentials.

Owners of inactive accounts will not notice if unauthorized access to their user account has been obtained.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: Executable search paths within the initialization files of all local interactive RHEL 9 users must only contain paths that resolve to the system default or the users home directory.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Executable search paths within the initialization files of all local interactive RHEL 9 users must only contain paths that resolve to the system default or the users home directory.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Edit the local interactive user initialization files to change any PATH variable statements that reference directories other than their home directory.

If a local interactive user requires path variables to reference a directory owned by the application, it must be documented with the ISSO.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes the current working directory (other than the users home directory), executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands.

This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon or two consecutive colons, this is interpreted as the current working directory. If deviations from the default system search path for the local interactive user are required, they must be documented with the information system security officer (ISSO).

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: All RHEL 9 local interactive users must have a home directory assigned in the /etc/passwd file.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All RHEL 9 local interactive users must have a home directory assigned in the /etc/passwd file.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Create and assign home directories to all local interactive users on RHEL 9 that currently do not have a home directory assigned.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: If local interactive users are not assigned a valid home directory, there is no place for the storage and control of files they should own.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: All RHEL 9 local interactive user home directories defined in the /etc/passwd file must exist.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All RHEL 9 local interactive user home directories defined in the /etc/passwd file must exist.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Create home directories to all local interactive users that currently do not have a home directory assigned. Use the following commands to create the user home directory assigned in "/etc/ passwd":

Note: The example will be for the user wadea, who has a home directory of "/home/wadea", a user identifier (UID) of "wadea", and a Group Identifier (GID) of "users assigned" in "/etc/passwd".

$ sudo mkdir /home/wadea 
$ sudo chown wadea /home/wadea
$ sudo chgrp users /home/wadea
$ sudo chmod 0750 /home/wadea

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: If a local interactive user has a home directory defined that does not exist, the user may be given access to the / directory as the current working directory upon logon. This could create a denial of service because the user would not be able to access their logon configuration files, and it may give them visibility to system files they normally would not be able to access.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: All RHEL 9 local interactive user home directories must be group-owned by the home directory owner's primary group.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All RHEL 9 local interactive user home directories must be group-owned by the home directory owner's primary group.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Change the group owner of a local interactive user's home directory to the group found in "/etc/passwd". To change the group owner of a local interactive user's home directory, use the following command:

Note: The example will be for the user "wadea", who has a home directory of "/home/wadea", and has a primary group of users.

$ sudo chgrp users /home/wadea

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: If the Group Identifier (GID) of a local interactive users home directory is not the same as the primary GID of the user, this would allow unauthorized access to the users files, and users that share the same group may not be able to access files that they legitimately should.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Enforce the organization-defined limit of consecutive invalid logon attempts by a user during the organization-defined time period.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Automatically lock the account or node for either an organization-defined time period, until the locked account or node is released by an administrator, or delays the next logon prompt according to the organization-defined delay algorithm when the maximum number of unsuccessful logon attempts is exceeded.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

Add/modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:

deny = 3

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128, SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must automatically lock the root account until the root account is released by an administrator when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Enforce the organization-defined limit of consecutive invalid logon attempts by a user during the organization-defined time period.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Automatically lock the account or node for either an organization-defined time period, until the locked account or node is released by an administrator, or delays the next logon prompt according to the organization-defined delay algorithm when the maximum number of unsuccessful logon attempts is exceeded.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must automatically lock the root account until the root account is released by an administrator when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
To configure RHEL 9 to lock out the "root" account after a number of incorrect logon attempts using "pam_faillock.so", first enable the feature using the following command:
 
$ sudo authselect enable-feature with-faillock  

Edit the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" by uncommenting or adding the following line:
 
even_deny_root

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, also known as brute-forcing, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128, SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Enforce the organization-defined limit of consecutive invalid logon attempts by a user during the organization-defined time period.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Automatically lock the account or node for either an organization-defined time period, until the locked account or node is released by an administrator, or delays the next logon prompt according to the organization-defined delay algorithm when the maximum number of unsuccessful logon attempts is exceeded.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
To configure RHEL 9 to lock out the "root" account after a number of incorrect logon attempts within 15 minutes using "pam_faillock.so", enable the feature using the following command:
 
$ sudo authselect enable-feature with-faillock  

Then edit the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file as follows:

fail_interval = 900

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
By limiting the number of failed logon attempts the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-forcing, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128, SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must maintain an account lock until the locked account is released by an administrator.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Enforce the organization-defined limit of consecutive invalid logon attempts by a user during the organization-defined time period.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Automatically lock the account or node for either an organization-defined time period, until the locked account or node is released by an administrator, or delays the next logon prompt according to the organization-defined delay algorithm when the maximum number of unsuccessful logon attempts is exceeded.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must maintain an account lock until the locked account is released by an administrator.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to lock an account until released by an administrator after three unsuccessful logon attempts with the command:
 
$ sudo authselect enable-feature with-faillock  

Edit the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file as follows:

unlock_time = 0

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
By limiting the number of failed logon attempts the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-forcing, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128, SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must not have unauthorized accounts.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must not have unauthorized accounts.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Remove unauthorized local interactive user accounts with the following command where <unauthorized_user> is the unauthorized account:

$ sudo userdel  <unauthorized_user>

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: Accounts providing no operational purpose provide additional opportunities for system compromise. Unnecessary accounts include user accounts for individuals not requiring access to the system and application accounts for applications not installed on the system.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: The root account must be the only account having unrestricted access to RHEL 9 system.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The root account must be the only account having unrestricted access to RHEL 9 system.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Change the UID of any account on the system, other than root, that has a UID of "0". 

If the account is associated with system commands or applications, the UID should be changed to one greater than "0" but less than "1000". Otherwise, assign a UID of greater than "1000" that has not already been assigned.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: An account has root authority if it has a user identifier (UID) of "0". Multiple accounts with a UID of "0" afford more opportunity for potential intruders to guess a password for a privileged account. Proper configuration of sudo is recommended to afford multiple system administrators access to root privileges in an accountable manner.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must ensure account lockouts persist.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Enforce the organization-defined limit of consecutive invalid logon attempts by a user during the organization-defined time period.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must ensure account lockouts persist.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 maintain the contents of the faillock directory after a reboot.

Add/modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:

dir = /var/log/faillock

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: Having lockouts persist across reboots ensures that account is only unlocked by an administrator. If the lockouts did not persist across reboots, an attacker could simply reboot the system to continue brute force attacks against the accounts on the system.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 groups must have unique Group ID (GID).

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Uniquely identify and authenticate organizational users and associate that unique identification with processes acting on behalf of those users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 groups must have unique Group ID (GID).

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Edit the file "/etc/group" and provide each group that has a duplicate GID with a unique GID.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: To ensure accountability and prevent unauthenticated access, groups must be identified uniquely to prevent potential misuse and compromise of the system.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: Local RHEL 9 initialization files must not execute world-writable programs.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Local RHEL 9 initialization files must not execute world-writable programs.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Set the mode on files being executed by the local initialization files with the following command:

$ sudo chmod 0755 <file>

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: If user start-up files execute world-writable programs, especially in unprotected directories, they could be maliciously modified to destroy user files or otherwise compromise the system at the user level. If the system is compromised at the user level, it is easier to elevate privileges to eventually compromise the system at the root and network level.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must automatically exit interactive command shell user sessions after 10 minutes of inactivity.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Prevent further access to the system by initiating a device lock after organization-defined time period of inactivity; and/or requiring the user to initiate a device lock before leaving the system unattended.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Terminate the network connection associated with a communications session at the end of the session or after an organization-defined time period of inactivity.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must automatically exit interactive command shell user sessions after 10 minutes of inactivity.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to exit interactive command shell user sessions after 10 minutes of inactivity.

Add or edit the following line in "/etc/profile.d/tmout.sh":

#!/bin/bash

declare -xr TMOUT=600

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Terminating an idle interactive command shell user session within a short time period reduces the window of opportunity for unauthorized personnel to take control of it when left unattended in a virtual terminal or physical console.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000163-GPOS-00072, SRG-OS-000029-GPOS-00010

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must limit the number of concurrent sessions to ten for all accounts and/or account types.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Limit the number of concurrent sessions for each organization-defined account and/or account type to an organization-defined number.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must limit the number of concurrent sessions to ten for all accounts and/or account types.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to limit the number of concurrent sessions to "10" for all accounts and/or account types.

Add the following line to the top of the /etc/security/limits.conf or in a ".conf" file defined in /etc/security/limits.d/:

* hard maxlogins 10

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Operating system management includes the ability to control the number of users and user sessions that utilize an operating system. Limiting the number of allowed users and sessions per user is helpful in reducing the risks related to denial-of-service (DoS) attacks.

This requirement addresses concurrent sessions for information system accounts and does not address concurrent sessions by single users via multiple system accounts. The maximum number of concurrent sessions must be defined based on mission needs and the operational environment for each system.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must log username information when unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Enforce the organization-defined limit of consecutive invalid logon attempts by a user during the organization-defined time period.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must log username information when unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to log username information when unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

Enable the feature using the following command:
 
$ sudo authselect enable-feature with-faillock 
 
Add/modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:

audit

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: Without auditing of these events, it may be harder or impossible to identify what an attacker did after an attack.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must enforce a delay of at least four seconds between logon prompts following a failed logon attempt.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must enforce a delay of at least four seconds between logon prompts following a failed logon attempt.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure the RHEL 9 to enforce a delay of at least four seconds between logon prompts following a failed console logon attempt.

Modify the "/etc/login.defs" file to set the "FAIL_DELAY" parameter to 4 or greater:

FAIL_DELAY 4

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: Increasing the time between a failed authentication attempt and reprompting to enter credentials helps to slow a single-threaded brute force attack.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must define default permissions for the bash shell.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must define default permissions for the bash shell.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to define default permissions for all authenticated users using the bash shell.

Add or edit the lines for the "umask" parameter in the "/etc/bashrc" file to "077":

umask 077

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files. A umask of 077 limits new files to mode 600 or less permissive. Although umask can be represented as a four-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be "0". This requirement applies to the globally configured system defaults and the local interactive user defaults for each account on the system.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00228, SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must define default permissions for the c shell.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must define default permissions for the c shell.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to define default permissions for all authenticated users using the c shell.

Add or edit the lines for the "umask" parameter in the "/etc/csh.cshrc" file to "077":

umask 077

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files. A umask of 077 limits new files to mode 600 or less permissive. Although umask can be represented as a four-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be "0". This requirement applies to the globally configured system defaults and the local interactive user defaults for each account on the system.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00228, SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must define default permissions for all authenticated users in such a way that the user can only read and modify their own files.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must define default permissions for all authenticated users in such a way that the user can only read and modify their own files.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to define default permissions for all authenticated users in such a way that the user can only read and modify their own files.

Add or edit the lines for the "UMASK" parameter in the "/etc/login.defs" file to "077":

UMASK 077

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: Setting the most restrictive default permissions ensures that when new accounts are created, they do not have unnecessary access.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must define default permissions for the system default profile.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must define default permissions for the system default profile.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to define default permissions for all authenticated users in such a way that the user can only read and modify their own files.

Add or edit the lines for the "umask" parameter in the "/etc/profile" file to "077":

umask 077

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files. A umask of 077 limits new files to mode 600 or less permissive. Although umask can be represented as a four-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be "0". This requirement applies to the globally configured system defaults and the local interactive user defaults for each account on the system.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00228, SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must display the date and time of the last successful account logon upon logon.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must display the date and time of the last successful account logon upon logon.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to provide users with feedback on when account accesses last occurred by setting the required configuration options in "/etc/pam.d/postlogin". 

Add the following line to the top of "/etc/pam.d/postlogin":

session required pam_lastlog.so showfailed

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: Users need to be aware of activity that occurs regarding their account. Providing users with information regarding the number of unsuccessful attempts that were made to login to their account allows the user to determine if any unauthorized activity has occurred and gives them an opportunity to notify administrators.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must terminate idle user sessions.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Terminate the network connection associated with a communications session at the end of the session or after an organization-defined time period of inactivity.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must terminate idle user sessions.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to log out idle sessions by editing the /etc/systemd/logind.conf file with the following line:

StopIdleSessionSec=900

The "logind" service must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the "logind" service, run the following command:

$ sudo systemctl restart systemd-logind

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: Terminating an idle session within a short time period reduces the window of opportunity for unauthorized personnel to take control of a management session enabled on the console or console port that has been left unattended.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must use a Linux Security Module configured to enforce limits on system services.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Isolate security functions from nonsecurity functions.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Verify correct operation of organization-defined security functions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must use a Linux Security Module configured to enforce limits on system services.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to verify correct operation of security functions.

Edit the file "/etc/selinux/config" and add or modify the following line:

 SELINUX=enforcing 

A reboot is required for the changes to take effect.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Without verification of the security functions, security functions may not operate correctly and the failure may go unnoticed. Security function is defined as the hardware, software, and/or firmware of the information system responsible for enforcing the system security policy and supporting the isolation of code and data on which the protection is based. Security functionality includes, but is not limited to, establishing system accounts, configuring access authorizations (i.e., permissions, privileges), setting events to be audited, and setting intrusion detection parameters.

This requirement applies to operating systems performing security function verification/testing and/or systems and environments that require this functionality.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000445-GPOS-00199, SRG-OS-000134-GPOS-00068

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must enable the SELinux targeted policy.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Verify correct operation of organization-defined security functions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must enable the SELinux targeted policy.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to use the targetd SELINUX policy.

Edit the file "/etc/selinux/config" and add or modify the following line:

 SELINUXTYPE=targeted 

A reboot is required for the changes to take effect.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Setting the SELinux policy to "targeted" or a more specialized policy ensures the system will confine processes that are likely to be targeted for exploitation, such as network or system services.

Note: During the development or debugging of SELinux modules, it is common to temporarily place nonproduction systems in "permissive" mode. In such temporary cases, SELinux policies should be developed, and once work is completed, the system should be reconfigured to "targeted".

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must configure SELinux context type to allow the use of a nondefault faillock tally directory.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Enforce the organization-defined limit of consecutive invalid logon attempts by a user during the organization-defined time period.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must configure SELinux context type to allow the use of a nondefault faillock tally directory.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to allow the use of a nondefault faillock tally directory while SELinux enforces a targeted policy. 

First enable the feature using the following command:
 
$ sudo authselect enable-feature with-faillock 
 
Create a nondefault faillock tally directory (if it does not already exist) with the following example:

$ sudo mkdir /var/log/faillock

Then add/modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:
 
dir = /var/log/faillock

Update the /etc/selinux/targeted/contexts/files/file_contexts.local with "faillog_t" context type for the nondefault faillock tally directory with the following command:

$ sudo semanage fcontext -a -t faillog_t "/var/log/faillock(/.*)?"

Next, update the context type of the nondefault faillock directory/subdirectories and files with the following command:

$ sudo restorecon -R -v /var/log/faillock

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: Not having the correct SELinux context on the faillock directory may lead to unauthorized access to the directory.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must have policycoreutils package installed.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Isolate security functions from nonsecurity functions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must have policycoreutils package installed.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
The policycoreutils package can be installed with the following command:
 
$ sudo dnf install policycoreutils

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Without verification of the security functions, security functions may not operate correctly and the failure may go unnoticed. Security function is defined as the hardware, software, and/or firmware of the information system responsible for enforcing the system security policy and supporting the isolation of code and data on which the protection is based. Security functionality includes, but is not limited to, establishing system accounts, configuring access authorizations (i.e., permissions, privileges), setting events to be audited, and setting intrusion detection parameters.

Policycoreutils contains the policy core utilities that are required for basic operation of an SELinux-enabled system. These utilities include load_policy to load SELinux policies, setfile to label filesystems, newrole to switch roles, and run_init to run /etc/init.d scripts in the proper context.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227, SRG-OS-000134-GPOS-00068

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 policycoreutils-python-utils package must be installed.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 policycoreutils-python-utils package must be installed.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Install the policycoreutils-python-utils service package (if the policycoreutils-python-utils service is not already installed) with the following command:

$ sudo dnf install policycoreutils-python-utils

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: The policycoreutils-python-utils package is required to operate and manage an SELinux environment and its policies. It provides utilities such as semanage, audit2allow, audit2why, chcat, and sandbox.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must have the sudo package installed.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Prevent non-privileged users from executing privileged functions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must have the sudo package installed.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
The  sudo  package can be installed with the following command:
 
$ sudo dnf install sudo

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: "sudo" is a program designed to allow a system administrator to give limited root privileges to users and log root activity. The basic philosophy is to give as few privileges as possible but still allow system users to get their work done.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must require reauthentication when using the "sudo" command.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Permit users to invoke the trusted communications path for communications between the user and the organization-defined security functions, including at a minimum, authentication and re-authentication.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The organization requires users to reauthenticate upon organization-defined circumstances or situations requiring reauthentication.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must require reauthentication when using the "sudo" command.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to reauthenticate "sudo" commands after the specified timeout:

Add the following line to "/etc/sudoers" or a file in "/etc/sudoers.d":

Defaults timestamp_timeout=0

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Without reauthentication, users may access resources or perform tasks for which they do not have authorization. 

When operating systems provide the capability to escalate a functional capability, it is critical the organization requires the user to reauthenticate when using the "sudo" command.

If the value is set to an integer less than "0", the user's time stamp will not expire and the user will not have to reauthenticate for privileged actions until the user's session is terminated.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must use the invoking user's password for privilege escalation when using "sudo".

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must use the invoking user's password for privilege escalation when using "sudo".

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Define the following in the Defaults section of the /etc/sudoers file or a single configuration file in the /etc/sudoers.d/ directory:

Defaults !targetpw
Defaults !rootpw
Defaults !runaspw

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: If the rootpw, targetpw, or runaspw flags are defined and not disabled, by default the operating system will prompt the invoking user for the "root" user password.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must require users to reauthenticate for privilege escalation.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Permit users to invoke the trusted communications path for communications between the user and the organization-defined security functions, including at a minimum, authentication and re-authentication.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The organization requires users to reauthenticate upon organization-defined circumstances or situations requiring reauthentication.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must require users to reauthenticate for privilege escalation.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to not allow users to execute privileged actions without authenticating.

Remove any occurrence of "!authenticate" found in "/etc/sudoers" file or files in the "/etc/sudoers.d" directory.

$ sudo sed -i '/\!authenticate/ s/^/# /g' /etc/sudoers /etc/sudoers.d/*

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Without reauthentication, users may access resources or perform tasks for which they do not have authorization.

When operating systems provide the capability to escalate a functional capability, it is critical that the user reauthenticate.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00156, SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00157, SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00158

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must restrict privilege elevation to authorized personnel.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must restrict privilege elevation to authorized personnel.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Remove the following entries from the /etc/sudoers file or configuration file under /etc/sudoers.d/:

ALL     ALL=(ALL) ALL
ALL     ALL=(ALL:ALL) ALL

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: If the "sudoers" file is not configured correctly, any user defined on the system can initiate privileged actions on the target system.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must restrict the use of the "su" command.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Permit users to invoke the trusted communications path for communications between the user and the organization-defined security functions, including at a minimum, authentication and re-authentication.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Enforce organization-defined discretionary access control policies over defined subjects and objects.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The organization requires users to reauthenticate upon organization-defined circumstances or situations requiring reauthentication.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must restrict the use of the "su" command.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to require users to be in the "wheel" group to run "su" command.

In file "/etc/pam.d/su", uncomment the following line:

"#auth    required    pam_wheel.so use_uid"

$ sed '/^[[:space:]]*#[[:space:]]*auth[[:space:]]\+required[[:space:]]\+pam_wheel\.so[[:space:]]\+use_uid$/s/^[[:space:]]*#//' -i /etc/pam.d/su

If necessary, create a "wheel" group and add administrative users to the group.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
The "su" program allows to run commands with a substitute user and group ID. It is commonly used to run commands as the root user. Limiting access to such commands is considered a good security practice.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00156, SRG-OS-000312-GPOS-00123

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 fapolicy module must be installed.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Prevent program execution in accordance with organization-defined policies, rules of behavior, and/or access agreements regarding software program usage and restrictions; rules authorizing the terms and conditions of software program usage.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Employ a deny-all, permit-by-exception policy to allow the execution of authorized software programs on the system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 fapolicy module must be installed.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
The  fapolicyd  package can be installed with the following command:
 
$ sudo dnf install fapolicyd

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as allow listing.

Utilizing an allow list provides a configuration management method for allowing the execution of only authorized software. Using only authorized software decreases risk by limiting the number of potential vulnerabilities. Verification of allow listed software occurs prior to execution or at system startup.

User home directories/folders may contain information of a sensitive nature. Nonprivileged users should coordinate any sharing of information with an SA through shared resources.

RHEL 9 ships with many optional packages. One such package is a file access policy daemon called "fapolicyd". "fapolicyd" is a userspace daemon that determines access rights to files based on attributes of the process and file. It can be used to either blocklist or allow list processes or file access.

Proceed with caution with enforcing the use of this daemon. Improper configuration may render the system nonfunctional. The "fapolicyd" API is not namespace aware and can cause issues when launching or running containers.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000370-GPOS-00155, SRG-OS-000368-GPOS-00154

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 fapolicy module must be enabled.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Prevent program execution in accordance with organization-defined policies, rules of behavior, and/or access agreements regarding software program usage and restrictions; rules authorizing the terms and conditions of software program usage.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Employ a deny-all, permit-by-exception policy to allow the execution of authorized software programs on the system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 fapolicy module must be enabled.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Enable the fapolicyd with the following command:

$ systemctl enable --now fapolicyd

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as allowlisting.

Utilizing an allowlist provides a configuration management method for allowing the execution of only authorized software. Using only authorized software decreases risk by limiting the number of potential vulnerabilities. Verification of allowlisted software occurs prior to execution or at system startup.

User home directories/folders may contain information of a sensitive nature. Nonprivileged users should coordinate any sharing of information with an SA through shared resources.

RHEL 9 ships with many optional packages. One such package is a file access policy daemon called "fapolicyd". "fapolicyd" is a userspace daemon that determines access rights to files based on attributes of the process and file. It can be used to either blocklist or allowlist processes or file access.

Proceed with caution with enforcing the use of this daemon. Improper configuration may render the system nonfunctional. The "fapolicyd" API is not namespace aware and can cause issues when launching or running containers.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000370-GPOS-00155, SRG-OS-000368-GPOS-00154

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must ensure the password complexity module in the system-auth file is configured for three retries or less.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: For password-based authentication, enforce organization-defined composition and complexity rules.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system enforces password complexity by the minimum number of upper case characters used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must ensure the password complexity module in the system-auth file is configured for three retries or less.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to limit the "pwquality" retry option to "3".

Add or update the following line in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" file or a file in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf.d/" directory to contain the "retry" parameter:
 
retry = 3

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. "pwquality" enforces complex password construction configuration and has the ability to limit brute-force attacks on the system.

RHEL 9 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. This is set in both:
/etc/pam.d/password-auth
/etc/pam.d/system-auth

By limiting the number of attempts to meet the pwquality module complexity requirements before returning with an error, the system will audit abnormal attempts at password changes.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must not allow blank or null passwords.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must not allow blank or null passwords.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
If PAM is managed with authselect, use the following command to remove instances of "nullok":
 
$ sudo authselect enable-feature without-nullok

Otherwise, remove any instances of the "nullok" option in the "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" and "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" files to prevent logons with empty passwords.

Note: Manual changes to the listed file may be overwritten by the "authselect" program.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: If an account has an empty password, anyone could log in and run commands with the privileges of that account. Accounts with empty passwords should never be used in operational environments.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must configure the use of the pam_faillock.so module in the /etc/pam.d/system-auth file.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Enforce the organization-defined limit of consecutive invalid logon attempts by a user during the organization-defined time period.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must configure the use of the pam_faillock.so module in the /etc/pam.d/system-auth file.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to include the use of the pam_faillock.so module in the /etc/pam.d/system-auth file. 

If PAM is managed with authselect, enable the feature with the following command:
 
$ sudo authselect enable-feature with-faillock
 
Otherwise, add/modify the appropriate sections of the "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" file to match the following lines:
Note: The "preauth" line must be listed before pam_unix.so.

auth required pam_faillock.so preauth
auth required pam_faillock.so authfail
account required pam_faillock.so

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: If the pam_faillock.so module is not loaded, the system will not correctly lockout accounts to prevent password guessing attacks.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must configure the use of the pam_faillock.so module in the /etc/pam.d/password-auth file.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Enforce the organization-defined limit of consecutive invalid logon attempts by a user during the organization-defined time period.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must configure the use of the pam_faillock.so module in the /etc/pam.d/password-auth file.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to include the use of the pam_faillock.so module in the /etc/pam.d/password-auth file. If PAM is managed with authselect, enable the feature with the following command:
 
$ sudo authselect enable-feature with-faillock

Otherwise, add/modify the appropriate sections of the "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" file to match the following lines:
Note: The "preauth" line must be listed before pam_unix.so.

auth required pam_faillock.so preauth
auth required pam_faillock.so authfail
account required pam_faillock.so

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: If the pam_faillock.so module is not loaded, the system will not correctly lockout accounts to prevent password guessing attacks.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must ensure the password complexity module is enabled in the password-auth file.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: For password-based authentication, enforce organization-defined composition and complexity rules.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system enforces password complexity by the minimum number of upper case characters used.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system enforces password complexity by the minimum number of lower case characters used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must ensure the password complexity module is enabled in the password-auth file.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to use "pwquality" to enforce password complexity rules.

Add the following line to the "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" file (or modify the line to have the required value):

password required pam_pwquality.so

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Enabling PAM password complexity permits enforcement of strong passwords and consequently makes the system less prone to dictionary attacks.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000069-GPOS-00037, SRG-OS-000070-GPOS-00038, SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must ensure the password complexity module is enabled in the system-auth file.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement the security configuration settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must ensure the password complexity module is enabled in the system-auth file.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to use "pwquality" to enforce password complexity rules.

Add the following line to the "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" file(or modify the line to have the required value):

password required pam_pwquality.so

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: Enabling PAM password complexity permits enforcement of strong passwords and consequently makes the system less prone to dictionary attacks.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 password-auth must be configured to use a sufficient number of hashing rounds.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: For password-based authentication, store passwords using an approved salted key derivation function, preferably using a keyed hash.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: Implement mechanisms for authentication to a cryptographic module that meet the requirements of applicable laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance for such authentication.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system, for password-based authentication, stores only cryptographically-protected passwords.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 password-auth must be configured to use a sufficient number of hashing rounds.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to use 100000 hashing rounds for hashing passwords.

Add or modify the following line in "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" and set "rounds" to "100000".

password sufficient pam_unix.so sha512 rounds=100000

Note: Running authselect will overwrite this value unless a custom authselect policy is created.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Passwords need to be protected at all times, and encryption is the standard method for protecting passwords. If passwords are not encrypted, they can be plainly read (i.e., clear text) and easily compromised. Passwords that are encrypted with a weak algorithm are no more protected than if they are kept in plain text.

Using more hashing rounds makes password cracking attacks more difficult.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000073-GPOS-00041, SRG-OS-000120-GPOS-00061

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

props.remarks: For password-based authentication, store passwords using an approved salted key derivation function, preferably using a keyed hash.

Note: Running authselect will overwrite this value unless a custom authselect policy is created.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000073-GPOS-00041, SRG-OS-000120-GPOS-00061

controls.title: RHEL 9 must enforce password complexity rules for the root account.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: For password-based authentication, enforce organization-defined composition and complexity rules.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system enforces password complexity by the minimum number of upper case characters used.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system enforces password complexity by the minimum number of lower case characters used.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system enforces password complexity by the minimum number of numeric characters used.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system, for password-based authentication, when new passwords are created, enforces that at least an organization-defined number of characters are changed.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system enforces minimum password length.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system enforces password complexity by the minimum number of special characters used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must enforce password complexity rules for the root account.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to enforce password complexity on the root account.

Add or update the following line in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" file or a configuration file in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf.d/" directory to contain the "enforce_for_root" parameter:

enforce_for_root

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000072-GPOS-00040, SRG-OS-000071-GPOS-00039, SRG-OS-000070-GPOS-00038, SRG-OS-000266-GPOS-00101, SRG-OS-000078-GPOS-00046, SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00225, SRG-OS-000069-GPOS-00037

controls.title: RHEL 9 must enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one lowercase character be used.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: For password-based authentication, enforce organization-defined composition and complexity rules.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system enforces password complexity by the minimum number of lower case characters used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one lowercase character be used.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to enforce password complexity by requiring at least one lowercase character be used by setting the "lcredit" option.

Add or update the following line in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" file or a configuration file in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf.d/" directory to contain the "lcredit" parameter:

lcredit = -1

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. 

Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. Requiring a minimum number of lowercase characters makes password guessing attacks more difficult by ensuring a larger search space.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

props.remarks: The information system enforces password complexity by the minimum number of numeric characters used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one numeric character be used.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to enforce password complexity by requiring at least one numeric character be used by setting the "dcredit" option.

Add or update the following line in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" file or a configuration file in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf.d/" directory to contain the "dcredit" parameter:

dcredit = -1

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. Requiring digits makes password guessing attacks more difficult by ensuring a larger search space.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 passwords for new users or password changes must have a 24 hours minimum password lifetime restriction in /etc/login.defs.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: For password-based authentication, enforce organization-defined composition and complexity rules.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system enforces minimum password lifetime restrictions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 passwords for new users or password changes must have a 24 hours minimum password lifetime restriction in /etc/login.defs.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to enforce 24 hours as the minimum password lifetime.

Add the following line in "/etc/login.defs" (or modify the line to have the required value):

PASS_MIN_DAYS 1

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Enforcing a minimum password lifetime helps to prevent repeated password changes to defeat the password reuse or history enforcement requirement. If users are allowed to immediately and continually change their password, then the password could be repeatedly changed in a short period of time to defeat the organization's policy regarding password reuse.

Setting the minimum password age protects against users cycling back to a favorite password after satisfying the password reuse requirement.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 passwords must be created with a minimum of 15 characters.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: For password-based authentication, enforce organization-defined composition and complexity rules.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system enforces minimum password length.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 passwords must be created with a minimum of 15 characters.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to enforce a minimum 15-character password length.

Add or update the following line in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" file or a configuration file in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf.d/" directory to contain the "minlen" parameter:

minlen = 15

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
The shorter the password, the lower the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. Password length is one factor of several that helps to determine strength and how long it takes to crack a password. Use of more characters in a password helps to increase exponentially the time and/or resources required to compromise the password.

RHEL 9 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. Configurations are set in the "etc/security/pwquality.conf" file.

The "minlen", sometimes noted as minimum length, acts as a "score" of complexity based on the credit components of the "pwquality" module. By setting the credit components to a negative value, not only will those components be required, but they will not count toward the total "score" of "minlen". This will enable "minlen" to require a 15-character minimum.

The DOD minimum password requirement is 15 characters.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

props.name: cci

Add or update the following line in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" file or a configuration file in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf.d/" directory to contain the "ocredit" parameter:

ocredit = -1

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. RHEL 9 utilizes "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. Note that to require special characters without degrading the "minlen" value, the credit value must be expressed as a negative number in "/etc/security/pwquality.conf".

parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

If RHEL 9 allows the user to select passwords based on dictionary words, this increases the chances of password compromise by increasing the opportunity for successful guesses, and brute-force attacks.

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. 

Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. Requiring a minimum number of different characters during password changes ensures that newly changed passwords will not resemble previously compromised ones. Note that passwords changed on compromised systems will still be compromised.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must be configured so that user and group account administration utilities are configured to store only encrypted representations of passwords.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: For password-based authentication, store passwords using an approved salted key derivation function, preferably using a keyed hash.

props.name: cci
props.remarks: The information system, for password-based authentication, stores only cryptographically-protected passwords.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must be configured so that user and group account administration utilities are configured to store only encrypted representations of passwords.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to use the SHA-512 algorithm for password hashing.

Add or change the following line in the "[defaults]" section of "/etc/libuser.conf" file:

crypt_style = sha512

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Passwords need to be protected at all times, and encryption is the standard method for protecting passwords. If passwords are not encrypted, they can be plainly read (i.e., clear text) and easily compromised. Passwords that are encrypted with a weak algorithm are no more protected than if they are kept in plain text.

This setting ensures user and group account administration utilities are configured to store only encrypted representations of passwords. Additionally, the "crypt_style" configuration option ensures the use of a strong hashing algorithm that makes password cracking attacks more difficult.

parts.name: assessment-method
parts.prose: Verify configuration meets the statement and guidance.

controls.title: RHEL 9 must be configured to use the shadow file to store only encrypted representations of passwords.

This setting ensures user and group account administration utilities are configured to store only encrypted representations of passwords. Additionally, the "crypt_style" configuration option ensures the use of a strong hashing algorithm that makes password cracking attacks more difficult.

parts.prose:
Configure all accounts on RHEL 9 to have a password or lock the account with the following commands:

Perform a password reset:

$ sudo passwd [username] 

To lock an account:

parts.prose: If an account has an empty password, anyone could log in and run commands with the privileges of that account. Accounts with empty passwords should never be used in operational environments.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RHEL 9 must use the common access card (CAC) smart card driver.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Configure RHEL 9 to load the CAC driver.

$ sudo opensc-tool --set-conf-entry app:default:card_driver:cac

Restart the pcscd service to apply the changes:

$ sudo systemctl restart pcscd

parts.name: vulnerability-discussion
parts.prose:
Smart card login provides two-factor authentication stronger than that provided by a username and password combination. Smart cards leverage public key infrastructure to provide and verify credentials. Configuring the smart card driver in use by the organization helps to prevent users from using unauthorized smart cards.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000104-GPOS-00051, SRG-OS-000106-GPOS-00053, SRG-OS-000107-GPOS-00054, SRG-OS-000109-GPOS-00056, SRG-OS-000108-GPOS-00055, SRG-OS-000112-GPOS-00057, SRG-OS-000113-GPOS-00058
